module_metadata.module_description: Understand what companies are, how they're structured, and what it means to own shares
learning_objectives: Understand different types of business structures
Learn what shares represent and shareholder rights
Learn about dividends and share valuation basics

content_blocks.content: Before understanding shares, you need to understand how businesses are structured. The structure determines ownership, liability, taxation, and how capital is raised.

content_blocks.definition: The legal organization of a business that defines ownership, liability, taxation, and operational framework.

properties.description: One person owns and runs the business
properties.bad_example: Owner personally liable for all debts. No separation between personal and business assets.

properties.description: Two or more people share ownership
properties.good_example: Law firms, CA firms, small businesses
properties.bad_example: Partners share profits and liabilities. Can be general or limited partnership.
Popular in India. Partners not personally liable for other partners' misconduct.

properties.description: Separate legal entity, shares not publicly traded
properties.bad_example: Limited liability, can't sell shares to public, max 200 shareholders.

properties.description: Can sell shares to public through stock exchanges
properties.bad_example: Strict regulations, transparent reporting, unlimited shareholders.
Introduced in 2013 in India. Best of sole proprietor + Pvt Ltd.

content_blocks.title: Evolution of a Business
content_blocks.content:
Raj starts as freelance web developer (Sole Proprietor):

Year 1: Just him, ₹5 lakh revenue
→ Sole Proprietorship works fine

Year 2: Hires 2 developers, ₹25 lakh revenue
→ Forms Partnership with co-founder

Year 3: Client sues for ₹50 lakh over contract dispute
→ Partnership means personal assets at risk! Converts to LLP for protection

Year 5: Revenue ₹2 crores, wants VC funding
→ Converts to Private Limited Company. Raises ₹5 crore at ₹20 crore valuation

Year 8: Revenue ₹100 crores, ready to scale
→ Goes public (IPO), becomes Public Limited Company, raises ₹500 crores

Each structure served its purpose at that stage.

points: Sole proprietor is simplest but personally risky
Private Limited offers liability protection and investor appeal
Public Limited can access public markets through stock exchanges
Structure choice depends on size, growth plans, and risk tolerance
Most startups begin as Pvt Ltd for flexibility and protection

quiz_check.question: Which business structure offers limited liability to a single owner?
quiz_check.explanation: One Person Company (OPC) provides limited liability protection to a single owner, combining the benefits of sole proprietorship's simplicity with private limited company's protection.

content_blocks.content: When you buy a share, you're buying a piece of a company. You become a part-owner, with rights and responsibilities. Understanding what shares represent is fundamental to investing.

content_blocks.definition: A unit of ownership in a company, representing a claim on the company's assets and earnings. Also called stock or equity.

pillars.description: You own a fraction of the company
pillars.explanation:
If company has 1 crore shares and you own 1 lakh shares:
• You own 1% of the company
• You own 1% of all assets (buildings, cash, inventory)
• You own 1% of future profits

Example: Own 1% of Reliance = You own 1% of all their refineries, telecom towers, retail stores!

• Vote in Annual General Meetings (AGM)
• Elect Board of Directors
• Approve major decisions (mergers, acquisitions)
• One share = one vote (usually)

Note: Some companies have different share classes with different voting rights.

Two ways to earn:

1. **Dividends**: Company distributes portion of profits to shareholders
2. **Capital Appreciation**: Share price increases as company grows

Example: Buy at ₹100, company grows, sell at ₹300 + received ₹20 in dividends = ₹220 total gain!

content_blocks.title: Calculating Your Ownership
content_blocks.example:
TCS has 369 crore shares outstanding.
You buy 10,000 shares.

Your ownership = (10,000 / 369,00,00,000) × 100
               = 0.0027%

You own 0.0027% of TCS!

Sounds tiny? If TCS profit is ₹40,000 crores:
Your share of profit = ₹40,000 crore × 0.0027%
                      = ₹1.08 crores worth of earnings attributed to your shares!
content_blocks.note: You don't get this cash directly—it's either paid as dividend or reinvested for growth.

items.risk: High - last to get paid in bankruptcy
items.typical: Most shares you see on stock market

items.rights: Fixed dividend, priority over equity, limited/no voting
items.return: Fixed dividend like bond + some upside

items.rights: Option to buy more shares at discount

content_blocks.title: Real Share Ownership
content_blocks.content:
You buy 100 shares of Infosys at ₹1,500 = ₹1,50,000 investment

Infosys total shares: 424 crore
Your ownership: 100 / 424,00,00,000 = 0.0000024%

**What you own:**
• 0.0000024% of ₹63,000 crore market cap = ₹1,50,000 ✓
• 0.0000024% of all offices globally
• 0.0000024% of ₹23,000 crore cash reserves
• 0.0000024% of future profits

**Your rights:**
• Receive annual report
• Vote in AGM (100 votes)
• Receive dividends (₹16/share last year = ₹1,600)
• Sell anytime on stock exchange

**Your obligations:**
• None! Limited liability. Can't lose more than ₹1,50,000.

content_blocks.title: Why Companies Issue Shares
content_blocks.content:
Companies issue shares to raise capital without taking debt:

**Advantages for Company:**
• No interest payments (unlike loans)
• No repayment required (unlike loans)
• Shared risk with investors
• Can raise massive amounts (Paytm IPO: ₹18,300 crores!)

**Cost to Company:**
• Dilution - founders own smaller %
• Loss of control if too many shares sold
• Pressure from shareholders for profits
• Disclosure requirements

Companies balance between selling shares (dilution) and taking loans (interest burden).

points: Shares represent fractional ownership of a company
Shareholders have voting rights and profit participation
Returns come from dividends and price appreciation
Equity shares have voting rights; preference shares have priority
Limited liability - you can't lose more than your investment

quiz_check.question: If a company has 10 crore shares and you own 50,000 shares, what % do you own?
quiz_check.explanation: Ownership = (50,000 / 10,00,00,000) × 100 = 0.05%. You own half of one-tenth of one percent of the company.

content_blocks.content: Not all companies can be bought and sold on stock exchanges. The difference between public and private companies determines who can invest and how shares are traded.

items.private: Limited to founders, VCs, invited investors
items.public: Anyone can buy through stock exchange

pillars.explanation:
1. **Raise Capital**: Billions from public investors
2. **Liquidity**: Early investors and employees can sell
3. **Valuation**: Market determines fair value
4. **Credibility**: Public companies have higher trust
5. **Currency for M&A**: Use shares to acquire other companies
6. **Employee rewards**: Stock options become valuable

Example: Zomato went public to raise ₹9,375 crores for expansion and provide exit to early investors.
pillars.strength: Transforms private startup to public corporation

pillars.explanation:
• Track record: 3 years of operation
• Profitability: Positive cash flows (or growth potential)
• Minimum issue size: ₹10 crores
• Net worth: Minimum ₹1 crore in 3 of last 5 years
• Promoter holding: Min 20% pre-issue
• Clean governance: No major fraud/violations

Process takes 4-6 months, costs 3-7% of funds raised.

• Quarterly financial results (within 45 days)
• Annual audited accounts
• Immediate disclosure of material events
• Board composition rules (independent directors)
• Insider trading restrictions
• AGM and shareholder rights

Cost: ₹1-5 crores annually for compliance

content_blocks.title: Zomato's Public Journey
content_blocks.content:
**Pre-IPO (Private Company):**
• Founded 2008, raised from Sequoia, Ant Financial, others
• Valuation in private rounds: $3.9 billion (₹29,000 crores)
• Shares illiquid - only specialized investors could buy
• No public disclosure of finances

**IPO (July 2021):**
• Raised ₹9,375 crores at ₹76/share
• Market cap: ₹60,000 crores
• Everyone could buy - from ₹15,000 investment
• Listed on BSE/NSE

**Post-IPO:**
• Share price fluctuated ₹76 → ₹150 → ₹40 → ₹110 (volatility!)
• Quarterly results public - losses visible to all
• Anyone can now invest/exit daily
• Permanent scrutiny from analysts, media, SEBI

steps.title: Startup (Private)
steps.description: Founders bootstrap or raise from friends/family. Company worth ₹1-5 crores.

steps.title: Series A/B/C (Private)
steps.description: Venture capital rounds. Valuation grows ₹50 crores → ₹500 crores → ₹2,000 crores.

steps.title: Late Stage (Private)
steps.description: Large PE funds invest. Valuation ₹5,000+ crores. Profitable or near-profitable.

steps.title: IPO (Going Public)
steps.description: List on stock exchange. Valuation ₹10,000+ crores. Retail investors can buy.

steps.title: Mature Public Company
steps.description: Established, stable, possibly dividend-paying. Part of indices like Nifty 50.

scenarios.description: Companies like Byju's, OYO, Ola (before IPO) have unlisted shares trading in grey market.
scenarios.effect: Can buy, but risky - no regulation, hard to sell, price not transparent

scenarios.description: Startup employees get stock options. Can't sell until IPO or company buyback.
scenarios.effect: Illiquid wealth - millionaire on paper but can't access money

scenarios.description: Wealthy investors buy stakes in private companies directly. Min investment ₹1-10 crores.
scenarios.effect: High risk, high return, very illiquid (5-10 year hold)

points: Private companies have restricted ownership; public companies trade freely
IPO is the process of going from private to public
Public companies face strict disclosure and governance requirements
Liquidity is the biggest advantage of public markets
Most startups stay private 8-12 years before IPO

quiz_check.question: What is the main advantage of a company going public through an IPO?
options: Ability to raise large capital and provide liquidity
quiz_check.explanation: IPO allows companies to raise significant capital from public investors and provides liquidity for early investors and employees to sell shares. It comes with increased regulation, not less.

content_blocks.content: Companies need capital to grow—build factories, hire people, expand to new markets. They can borrow (debt) or sell ownership (equity). Understanding capital raising is key to evaluating investment opportunities.

items.risk_to_company: Fixed obligation - must pay even in losses
items.best_for: Established companies with steady cash flow

items.risk_to_company: Shared with investors - no fixed obligation

pillars.explanation:
Company's debut on stock exchange:

• **Fresh Issue**: Company creates new shares, gets the money
• **Offer for Sale (OFS)**: Existing shareholders sell their shares, company gets nothing
• **Mix**: Usually combination of both

Example: Paytm IPO (2021)
• Fresh issue: ₹8,300 crores → Company gets this
• OFS: ₹10,000 crores → Early investors encash
• Total: ₹18,300 crores IPO

After IPO, company can raise again:

• Dilutes existing shareholders further
• Usually at market price or small discount
• Common for banks, capital-intensive businesses

Example: Yes Bank FPO (2020) raised ₹15,000 crores to recover from crisis
pillars.strength: Access to capital without new debt

pillars.explanation:
Company offers new shares to current shareholders:

• In proportion to existing holdings
• Usually at 10-20% discount to market price
• Can accept, sell rights, or ignore

Example: Own 100 shares, company offers 1:4 rights
• You can buy 25 more shares at discount
• Or sell your right to someone else

Listed companies can sell to:

• Mutual funds, insurance companies, FIIs
• Minimum ₹2 lakh per investor
• Faster, cheaper than public offering
• Retail investors excluded

Example: Reliance QIP (2020) raised ₹53,125 crores from institutions
pillars.strength: Quick, large capital from sophisticated investors

content_blocks.title: Reliance's Capital Raising Marathon (2020)
content_blocks.content:
Reliance needed capital to reduce debt:

**April-July 2020:**
• Facebook: ₹43,574 crores for 9.99% of Jio
• Google: ₹33,737 crores for 7.73% of Jio
• Silver Lake, Vista, others: ₹75,000+ crores
• Rights Issue: ₹53,125 crores from existing shareholders

**Total raised: ₹2,00,000+ CRORES in 4 months!**

**Result:**
• Debt reduced from ₹1.6 lakh crores to ₹80,000 crores
• Promoter ownership diluted from 50% to 45%
• Company became debt-free by 2021

This shows the power of equity markets for capital access.

content_blocks.title: Understanding Dilution
content_blocks.formula: New Ownership % = Old Shares / (Old Shares + New Shares Issued)
content_blocks.example:
You own 10,000 shares of company with 1 crore total shares.
Your ownership: 10,000 / 1,00,00,000 = 0.01%

Company raises capital by issuing 50 lakh new shares:

Your new ownership:
= 10,000 / (1,00,00,000 + 50,00,000)
= 10,000 / 1,50,00,000
= 0.0067%

You were diluted from 0.01% to 0.0067% (33% dilution!)

However, if the capital raised grows company value by more than dilution, you still win.
content_blocks.note: Dilution is okay if capital is used productively to grow the business.

scenarios.description: Repeatedly raised capital (loans + equity) but business model was broken. Money went into operations, not growth.
Tried to raise $3 billion at $47B valuation. Prospectus revealed massive losses, questionable governance.
scenarios.effect: IPO cancelled. Valuation crashed from $47B to $8B. CEO ousted.

scenarios.description: TCS rarely raises capital—generates profits to fund growth. IPO was in 2004, hasn't needed capital since.
scenarios.effect: Best companies rarely need capital. Consistent profit generation.

points: Companies raise capital through debt (loans) or equity (shares)
IPO is first public offering; FPO is subsequent capital raise
Rights issues protect existing shareholders from dilution
Dilution reduces your ownership % but can be beneficial if capital is used well
Best companies generate profits and rarely need external capital

quiz_check.question: What happens to your ownership percentage when a company issues new shares?
quiz_check.explanation: When a company issues new shares, your ownership percentage gets diluted because your fixed number of shares now represents a smaller portion of a larger total share count.

lessons.title: Dividends: Sharing Profits
lessons.subtitle: How Companies Return Cash to Shareholders

content_blocks.content: Dividends are cash payments companies make to shareholders from profits. It's one of two ways you earn from shares (the other being price appreciation). Understanding dividends helps evaluate income-generating investments.

content_blocks.definition: A portion of company profits distributed to shareholders, usually as cash payment per share, decided by the board of directors.

content_blocks.title: Key Dividend Metrics
content_blocks.formula:
Dividend Yield = (Annual Dividend per Share / Share Price) × 100

Dividend Payout Ratio = (Total Dividends / Net Profit) × 100
content_blocks.example:
Coal India:
• Share price: ₹250
• Annual dividend: ₹20/share
• Net profit: ₹30,000 crores
• Total dividends paid: ₹13,000 crores

Dividend Yield = (20 / 250) × 100 = 8%
(You earn 8% annually from dividends alone!)

Payout Ratio = (13,000 / 30,000) × 100 = 43%
(Company distributes 43% of profits, retains 57% for growth)
content_blocks.note: High yield is good for income, but check if it's sustainable.

pillars.explanation:
• Declared by board anytime
• Based on half-year or quarterly results
• Quick cash to shareholders

Example: Infosys declares ₹15 interim dividend in October based on good Q2 results
pillars.strength: Faster returns, doesn't wait for year-end

pillars.explanation:
• Proposed by board, approved by shareholders in AGM
• Based on full-year performance
• Paid once annually

Example: TCS proposes ₹40 final dividend after ₹45,000 crore annual profit

• When company has excess cash
• After asset sale or windfall profit
• Not regular, shouldn't be expected

Example: Company sells division for ₹10,000 crores, pays ₹50 special dividend to share proceeds

items.example: Amazon never paid dividend, stock up 200,000% since IPO

steps.title: Declaration Date
steps.description: Board announces dividend. Example: 'Board declares ₹10/share dividend'

steps.title: Ex-Dividend Date
steps.description: Must own shares BEFORE this date to get dividend. Buy on/after ex-date = no dividend

steps.title: Record Date
steps.description: Company checks who owns shares. If your name is in records = you get dividend

steps.title: Payment Date
steps.description: Money credited to your bank account. Usually 7-30 days after record date

content_blocks.title: Real Dividend Scenario
content_blocks.content:
You own 500 shares of HDFC Bank at ₹1,600/share

**April 20:** HDFC declares ₹19.50 dividend/share
**Ex-date: May 1**
**Record date: May 3**
**Payment date: May 15**

You bought shares on April 25 (before ex-date) ✓

**May 1:** Share price drops from ₹1,600 to ₹1,581 (₹19 drop = dividend amount)

**May 15:** ₹9,750 credited to your account
• 500 shares × ₹19.50 = ₹9,750
• Minus 10% TDD (dividend tax) = ₹975
• Net received: ₹8,775

Your shares are now worth ₹1,581 each + you got ₹8,775 cash. Total value same, but you have cash!

content_blocks.title: Why Share Price Drops on Ex-Dividend Date
content_blocks.content:
On ex-dividend date, share price typically falls by dividend amount:

Before ex-date: ₹100 (includes right to ₹5 dividend)
On ex-date: ₹95 (dividend entitlement removed)

Why?
• Buyers after ex-date don't get dividend
• So they won't pay full price
• Market auto-adjusts price down

Your total wealth doesn't change:
Before: 100 shares × ₹100 = ₹10,000
After: 100 shares × ₹95 + ₹500 dividend = ₹10,000

This is called 'dividend neutral' - no free lunch!

points: Dividends are profit distributions to shareholders
Dividend yield = annual dividend / share price
Must own shares before ex-dividend date to receive dividend
High dividend companies are good for income; growth companies reinvest
Share price drops by dividend amount on ex-dividend date

quiz_check.question: If a stock trades at ₹500 and pays ₹25 annual dividend, what is the dividend yield?
quiz_check.explanation: Dividend Yield = (Annual Dividend / Share Price) × 100 = (25 / 500) × 100 = 5%. You earn 5% annually from dividends alone.

lessons.title: Basic Share Valuation
lessons.subtitle: What Makes a Share Worth Its Price?

content_blocks.content: Why is TCS share ₹3,500 while HDFC Bank is ₹1,600? What determines share price? Understanding basic valuation helps you identify if a stock is expensive or cheap.

content_blocks.definition: Total value of all company shares. Calculated as: Share Price × Total Shares Outstanding. It's the price to buy the entire company.

content_blocks.title: Market Capitalization
content_blocks.formula: Market Cap = Share Price × Total Shares Outstanding
content_blocks.example:
Reliance:
• Share price: ₹2,500
• Total shares: 676 crore

Market Cap = 2,500 × 676,00,00,000
           = ₹16,90,000 crores
           = ₹16.9 lakh crores

This means stock market values entire Reliance at ₹16.9 lakh crores. To buy 100% ownership, you'd need this much (theoretically).
content_blocks.note: Market cap determines company size, not share price!

items.characteristics: Stable, mature, lower growth, less volatile

pillars.explanation:
P/E = Share Price / Earnings Per Share (EPS)

Tells you: How many years of profit needed to recover share price

Example:
• Share price: ₹1,000
• Annual profit per share (EPS): ₹50
• P/E = 1,000 / 50 = 20x

Meaning: At current earnings, takes 20 years to earn back your investment

Low P/E (<15) = Cheap
Medium P/E (15-25) = Fair
High P/E (>25) = Expensive (or high growth expected)

pillars.description: Price vs book value of assets
pillars.explanation:
P/B = Share Price / Book Value Per Share

Book Value = Total Assets - Total Liabilities

Example:
• Share price: ₹800
• Book value per share: ₹400
• P/B = 800 / 400 = 2x

Meaning: Paying 2x the accounting value of assets

Useful for: Banks, real estate, manufacturing
P/B < 1 = Trading below asset value (cheap or troubled)
P/B > 3 = Premium for growth/quality

Yield = (Annual Dividend / Price) × 100

• 2-3% = Low (growth companies)
• 4-6% = Good (balanced)
• 7-10% = High (mature businesses)

Compare with FD rates (6-7%): If stock yields 8% + has growth potential, better than FD!

content_blocks.title: Comparing Two Companies
content_blocks.content:
**Company A: TCS**
• Share Price: ₹3,500
• EPS: ₹130
• P/E: 27x (expensive!)
• Book Value/Share: ₹280
• P/B: 12.5x
• Dividend Yield: 2.1%
• Market Cap: ₹13 lakh crores (Large Cap)

**Company B: Regional IT Company**
• Share Price: ₹150
• EPS: ₹20
• P/E: 7.5x (cheap!)
• Book Value/Share: ₹100
• P/B: 1.5x
• Dividend Yield: 5%
• Market Cap: ₹2,000 crores (Small Cap)

**Analysis:**
Company B looks cheaper on all metrics. But TCS commands premium for:
• Quality and brand
• Global scale
• Consistent growth
• Lower risk

Metrics alone don't tell full story. Context matters!

items.example: IT boom → All IT stocks rise

content_blocks.title: Why Absolute Share Price Doesn't Matter
content_blocks.content:
Common mistake: 'TCS at ₹3,500 is expensive, XYZ at ₹50 is cheap!'

**Wrong thinking!** Share price alone is meaningless.

What matters:
• Market Cap (total value)
• P/E (price vs earnings)
• Growth prospects
• Quality of business

Example:
• MRF: ₹1,00,000/share (highest in India)
• Market cap: ₹42,000 crores

Vs

• Reliance: ₹2,500/share
• Market cap: ₹16,90,000 crores

Reliance is 40x larger despite lower share price!

Remember: Price per share = Total value / Number of shares

Companies can split shares (1 → 2) to reduce price. Doesn't change total value.

points: Market cap (price × shares) determines company size, not share price
P/E ratio shows how expensive shares are relative to earnings
Lower P/E isn't always better - quality commands premium
Compare companies within same industry for meaningful insights
Absolute share price (₹100 vs ₹1,000) is irrelevant - look at valuation metrics

quiz_check.question: A company has 10 crore shares trading at ₹500 each. What is its market cap?
quiz_check.explanation: Market Cap = Share Price × Total Shares = ₹500 × 10,00,00,000 = ₹5,000 crores. This is the total value of the company.

module_quiz.title: Companies & Shareholding - Final Assessment
module_quiz.description: Test your understanding of company structures and shares

questions.question: Which business structure provides limited liability to a single owner?
questions.explanation: One Person Company (OPC) offers limited liability protection to a single owner, combining sole proprietorship's simplicity with private company's protection.

questions.question: What does owning shares in a company represent?
questions.explanation: Shares represent fractional ownership of a company, granting voting rights and participation in profits through dividends and capital appreciation.

questions.question: If a company has 50 crore shares and you own 25,000, what % do you own?
questions.explanation: Ownership = (25,000 / 50,00,00,000) × 100 = 0.005%. You own five-thousandths of one percent.

questions.question: What is the main difference between public and private companies?
options: Public company shares can be traded on stock exchanges
questions.explanation: Public companies (limited) can sell shares on stock exchanges to anyone. Private companies (Pvt Ltd) have restricted ownership and can't list on exchanges.

questions.question: What happens to your ownership when a company issues new shares?
questions.explanation: When new shares are issued, your fixed number of shares represents a smaller percentage of the now-larger total, resulting in dilution.

questions.question: What is an IPO?
options: Initial Public Offering - first sale of shares to public
questions.explanation: IPO (Initial Public Offering) is when a private company first sells shares to the public and lists on a stock exchange.

questions.question: What is a dividend?
options: Distribution of company profits to shareholders
questions.explanation: Dividend is a cash payment from company profits distributed to shareholders, usually per share owned.

questions.question: If a stock trades at ₹400 and pays ₹20 annual dividend, what is the dividend yield?
questions.explanation: Dividend Yield = (20 / 400) × 100 = 5%. You earn 5% annually from dividends alone.

questions.question: What is market capitalization?
questions.explanation: Market Cap = Share Price × Total Shares Outstanding. It represents the total market value of all company shares.

questions.question: A company with share price ₹800, EPS ₹40. What is its P/E ratio?
questions.explanation: P/E Ratio = Share Price / EPS = 800 / 40 = 20x. It would take 20 years of current earnings to equal the share price.

questions.question: When must you own shares to receive a declared dividend?
questions.explanation: You must own shares before the ex-dividend date to be eligible for the dividend. Buying on or after ex-date means no dividend for you.

questions.question: Which is typically considered a 'large cap' company in India?
questions.explanation: Large cap companies have market capitalization above ₹20,000 crores. They're typically established, stable companies like TCS, Reliance, HDFC Bank.

completion_badge.title: Shareholding Master
completion_badge.description: Mastered company structures and share ownership
